dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dramatic baroque music. Diagonal crane shot of Langford, elegant country residence. Liveried footman carry trunks an impressive carriage.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (Wistfully sententious) Langford, Langford! If only it hadn't been for Langford - how happy we might have been! The sound of a sob, a fashionable young woman, MISS MARIA MANWARING, runs into frame heading to the house, crying. elder brother, LORD MANWARING -- an impressive figure - e as she enters, pursued by a thin, haggard yet rather youn woman -- LADY LUCY MANWARING, his wife.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY MANWARING
dialogues.text: Manwaring! Manwaring! Don't turn your back to me! Please! I can't bear it! Manwaring approaches a stunningly beautiful woman accompa by a drably cloaked girl, her face hidden in the shadow o her hood. Manwaring and a servant help the two into a carriage. An idiotic young fop, SIR JAMES MARTIN, hurries into fram

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: Lady Susan! Frederica! Wait! I beg you... As Sir James nears the carriage it pulls out; he’s left i the drive, lace kerchief to face, watching them go. Title card: ‘Churchill’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A footman lights candles as an attractive young woman, MR CATHERINE VERNON writes at her desk. CHARLES VERNON, her husband, approaches as the footman leaves.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Catherine, a letter-- Charles enters with a letter. He is calm and bland; he si

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --it seems Lady Susan will finally visit... REGINALD DECOURCY, Catherine's brother, enters in riding clothes as if about to head out for a jaunt.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In fact she's already on her way.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: What? He gives her the letter which she starts to read.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Lady Susan Vernon? Catherine nods. REGINALD (CONT’D) Congratulations on being about to receive the most accomplished flirt in all England!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: You misjudge her, Reginald.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Like many women of beauty and distinction our sister-in-law has been a victim of the spirit of jealousy in our land.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: It's jealousy?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Yes. Like anyone, Susan might be capable of an action or remark open to misconstruction but I cannot but admire the fortitude with which she has supported grave misfortunes.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Excuse me -- I spoke out of turn. Catherine’s look is that he did not speak out of turn; do bark outside; Charles leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would Lady Susan, who was so well settled at Langford, suddenly want to visit us?

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: What reason does she give?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: (reading) Her “anxiety to meet” me and to “know the children." These have never concerned her before. Reginald finishes pulling on his riding gloves, a reflect look on his face as if anticipating the meeting. TITLE CARD: ‘Edward Street, London’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALICIA JOHNSON, a pretty woman of fashion, floats down th hall as a doorbell sounds. A servant opens the front door revealing LADY SUSAN, the beautiful young woman glimpsed earlier. Alicia hurries her inside.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Susan! Come - hurry.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: My dear, such haste! How curious you are.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnson's carriage is about to come into the street...

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (laughs) Surely that must happen often...

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: You didn’t receive my letter?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Letter?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnson forbids my seeing you.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Preposterous! How can he “forbid?”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By threatening the severest punishment imaginable -- sending me back to Connecticut.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: To be tarred-and-feathered?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: He now claims to have important business at Hartford and threatens to settle there if our connection is not entirely severed.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: For what possible reason or pretext?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: His former ward, Lucy Manwaring, wrote to him.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Did she? Alicia slips Lucy Manwaring’s letter from the desk drawer hands it to Susan as they both sit.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A horrid woman!

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Deranged. If she were going to be jealous she should not have married such a charming man! I recall thinking as I approached Langford: (dramatically) "I like this Man; pray Heaven no harm come of it!" I was determined to be discreet and I have been -- admitting no one's attentions but Manwaring’s, avoiding general flirtation entirely... Except for a little notice bestowed on Sir James Martin. But if the world knew my motive there it would honor me!

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Martin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James Martin, of Martindale. Vastly rich and rather simple.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Ideal.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Miss Maria Manwaring had set her cap for him, considering such an income too large not to be shared. But with a little notice I detached him and soon had him in love with Frederica. If my daughter were not the greatest simpleton on earth she'd be engaged to him now!

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: She refused him! A baronet with ten thousand a year. It's all so provoking.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: But where will you live?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Were there another place open to me, I would crawl there on my knees: the worst spot this side of the ocean, a Country Village: Churchill, my brother-in-law's seat. Mrs. Cross, a gentlewoman in straitened circumstances who will come as my companion -- to pack, unpack, that sort of thing. As there’s an element of friendship involved I’m sure the paying of wages would be offensive to us both... EXT. A COUNTRY ROAD -- DAY. Lady Susan, beautiful in travelling clothes, rides a carr accompanied by her companion, MRS. CROSS:

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: ...-My brother-in-law, Charles Vernon, is very rich. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once a man gets his name on a Banking House he rolls in money -- so it is not very rational for his lady to begrudge the sums he has advanced me.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CROSS
dialogues.text: Decidedly irrational, not rational at all.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I have no money -- and no husband -- -- but in one’s plight they say is one’s opportunity. Not that I would ever want to think in opportunistic terms...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CROSS
dialogues.text: Certainly not. Never. The COACHMAN turns to them and shouts:

dialogues.speaker: COACHMAN
dialogues.text: Churchill, coming into view, your Ladyship. Lady Susan looks to the distance. An impressive ancient castle appears from behind the greenery:

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Heavens... What a bore.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CROSS
dialogues.text: Yes, decidedly boring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crane shot as the carriage pulls into the drive before “Churchill,” as Charles and the young children descend th steps to greet them. Footmen help the ladies from the carriage; Lady Susan pays particular attention to little Frederick. INT. CHURCHILL, MAIN HALL -—- DAY The butler, WILSON, exasperated, leads a footman across t hall:

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cross is a friend of Lady Susan and should be in the adjoining room.  INT. CHURCHILL, SUSAN’S ROOMS -- DAY Lady Susan enters as Mrs. Cross unpacks her trunk.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I have no reason to complain of Mr. Vernon's reception but I’m not entirely satisfied with his lady’s.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CROSS
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: She's perfectly well-bred, surprisingly so, but her manner doesn’t persuade me that she's disposed in my favour. A sympathetic look of agreement from Mrs. Cross.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As you might have noticed I sought to be as amiable as possible--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CROSS
dialogues.text: Exceptionally amiable. In fact entirely charming -- excuse me for saying so--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Not at all -- it's true. I wanted her to be delighted with me-- (disappointed) --but I didn’t succeed.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CROSS
dialogues.text: I can't understand it. Susan, thoughtful, recalls:

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It’s true I have always detested her. And that, before her marriage, I went to great lengths to prevent it. Yet it shows an illiberal spirit to resent for long a plan which didn’t succeed.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CROSS
dialogues.text: Decidedly illiberal. Not liberal at all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My opposing her marriage -- and later preventing her and Charles from buying Vernon Castle -- might have given her an unfavorable impression. But I’ve found that, where there’s a disposition to dislike, a pretext will soon be found.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CROSS
dialogues.text: You mustn’t reproach yourself--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I shan't -- the past is done. My project will be the children. I know a couple of their names already and have decided to attach myself to young Frederick in particular, taking him on my lap and sighing over him for his dear Uncle's sake-- A knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come in. Wilson enters.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Mrs. Vernon's compliments, your ladyship. She asks if you and Mrs. Cross would join her for tea?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: With pleasure-- She exchanges a look with Mrs. Cross.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cross would prefer her repose but thank Mrs. Vernon -- I will join her directly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A footman crosses out while Catherine checks the tea sett the sounds of children come from off-screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Frederick, I see you have quite an appetite: you will grow tall and handsome like your uncle -- and father.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE CHARLOTTE VERNON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Frederick, be good... Catherine smiles and approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE CHARLOTTE VERNON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frederick, don’t touch that!

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Frederick, be careful. The off-screen clatter of metal objects.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry! From off, Susan laughs, then enters with a gash of red ja her dress.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Not at all. Such a family resemblance -- it rather moves me.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: You’1l want to change. Susan covers the mark with a napkin and smoothly sits.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Oh no -- let’s have our tea while it’s warm. Mrs. Cross is a genius with fabrics. Catherine serves the tea. Susan takes her cup.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Oh yes! How much Frederick reminds me of his dear uncle!

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: You think there's a resemblance?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes, remarkable -- the eyes...  10. Catherine considers this:

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Weren’t Frederick Vernon's eyes brown?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (using her hand) I refer to the shape and slope of the brow...

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I must thank you for this visit -- I'm afraid the short notice must have come as a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Only because I understood you to be so happily settled at Langford.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It's true -- Lady Manwaring and her husband made me feel welcome. But their sunny dispositions led them often into society. I might have tolerated such a life at one time but the loss of a husband such as Mr. Vernon is not borne easily. To stay with you here, at your charming retirement-- (she looks around) --became my fondest wish...

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I was glad to have the chance to meet.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Might I confide something? Catherine nods.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Langford was not ideal for my daughter. Her education has been neglected, for which I fault myself -- Mr. Vernon's illness prevented my paying her the attention both duty and affection required. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have therefore placed her at the excellent school Miss Summers keeps.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I trust Frederica will visit soon.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: A visit, as delightful as that might be, would represent so many days and hours deducted from the “Grand Affair of Education.” And I’m afraid Frederica can’t afford such deductions.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: But she'll come for Christmas--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Alas, no: Miss Summers can only give her the concentrated attention she needs then. Susan puts down her cup and glances at the jam stain.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Not at all! If you’1ll excuse me I‘1ll give it to Mrs. Cross who, once rested, craves activity. She gets up.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Once she’s applied her genius to it all trace of little Frederick’s interesting design will disappear! Susan leaves; Catherine is left, looking pensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Mrs. Cross works on the dress stain, Lady Susan rea correspondence:

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The fees at Frederica’s school are far too high to even think of paying! So, in a sense, it’s an economy...  12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reginald arrives at a trot and dismounts, his horse held retainer. Removing his gloves he bounds up the front step

dialogues.speaker: EVENING
dialogues.text: Catherine with Reginald as he shakes off the cold; servan light candles.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: .-.I confess to curiosity to know this lady and see first-hand her bewitching powers. Is she as beautiful as they say?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: You worry me, Reginald.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Don’t. I understand Lady Susan possesses a degree of captivating deceit which might be pleasing to detect.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: You truly worry me.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Good evening! Lady Susan and Mrs. Cross enter from the garden or hallwa weather dependent. Reginald and Catherine are struck momentarily silent.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What charming expressions! Catherine recovers first:

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Susan, let me introduce my brother, Reginald DeCourcy. Reginald, may I present Frederick Vernon’s widow, Lady Susan, and her friend, Mrs. Cross. After a polite nod to Mrs. Cross, Reginald addresses Susa  13.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Delighted to make your acquaintance: Your renown precedes you.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (long pause; coolly) I’m afraid the allusion escapes me.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Your reputation as an ornament to our Society... Susan pauses a moment to collect her thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What you say surprises me. Since the great sadness of my husband’s death I have lived in nearly perfect isolation. To better know his family, and further remove myself from Society, I came to Churchill -- not to make new acquaintance of a frivolous sort. But of course I’m pleased to know my sister’s relations... MONTAGE with period music -- First, beautiful wide landsc view; Lady Susan and Reginald walk their horses after a r then another time they walk in the garden. And are observ doing so: Mrs. Cross pauses from attending to Susan’s wardrobe to look down upon them in the garden. INT. CHURCHILL, SUSAN’S ROOMS -- DAY Susan who returns in outdoor clothes pulling off her glov Mrs. Cross -- still pleased to take care of Lady Susan’s rooms and wardrobe -- warmly greets her.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CROSS
dialogues.text: I take it you are finding Mr. DeCourcy’s society more agreeable? Susan doesn’t disagree -- thinking...

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: To some degree... At first his conversation betrayed a sauciness and familiarity which is my aversion -- but since I’ve found a quality of callow idealism which rather interests me. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When I've inspired him with a greater respect than his sister's kind offices have allowed he might in fact be an agreeable flirt.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CROSS
dialogues.text: He’s handsome, isn’t he? Susan considers.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes. In a calf-like way -- not like Manwaring, of course. But there’s a certain pleasure in making a person, pre-determined to dislike, instead acknowledge one's superiority. How delightful it will be to humble the pride of these pompous DeCourcys! CARD: “Parklands, ancestral estate of the DeCourcy family

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The distinguished Sir Reginald DeCourcy walks through the impressive halls a letter in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady DeCourcy, mother of Catherine and Reginald, takes te the sofa, as Sir Reginald enters.

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: A letter for you, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: A letter?

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: From Catherine.

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: I hope she'll arrive soon. Lady DeCourcy takes the letter from him; she has the snif from a cold. LADY DECOURCY (CONT’D) The season’s cheerless without the children. Having trouble reading the letter, she puts it aside.  15. LADY DECOURCY (CONT’D) I'm afraid this cold has affected my eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: Save your eyes, my dear - I'll read for you.

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: No, that's all right--

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: I insist. Sir Reginald starts to read a moment to himself, then alo SIR REGINALD (CONT’D) Alright, now let’s see-- (reading & paraphrasing) Catherine hopes you are well... She asks most particularly that you give me her love. He looks to her expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: Yes, and..? Sir Reginald continues reading, mumbling a bit as he does

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: Reginald's decided to stay at Churchill to hunt with Charles. He cites the “fine open weather...” He looks out the window. SIR REGINALD (CONT’D) What nonsense. The weather’s not open at all!

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: Maybe it is there, or was when she wrote. (sweetly) My dear, could you just read?

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: Verbatim?

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: Yes, the words - some of Catherine’s voice will be in them.  16.

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: I'll read each word, comma and dash if that's what you wish. Here: "I grow deeply uneasy (comma) my dearest Mother (comma) about Reginald (comma) from witnessing the very rapid increase of her influence (semi-colon) --

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: Just the words, please.

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: No punctuation at all? All right, much easier: "He and Lady Susan are now on terms of the most particular friendship, frequently engaged in long conversations together." Lady Susan?

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: Yes Lady Susan has been visiting Churchill.

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: Lady Susan Vernon?!

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: How could Reginald engage in conversations with Lady Susan Vernon? Conversations which are... “long.” What would they talk about?

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: My eyes have definitely cleared -- I‘1ll read it myself. Don't trouble yourself...

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: No, no, if my son and heir is involved with such a lady I must trouble myself: (reading) “How sincerely do I grieve she ever entered this house! Her power over him is boundless: She has not only entirely effaced his former ill- opinion but persuaded him to justify her conduct in the most passionate of terms...”  17. Sir Reginald puts down the letter. SIR REGINALD (CONT’D) Well I must go--

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: No - I'll write--

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: No, no, if this is happening, there’s no time. Sir Reginald heads off to prepare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reginald rides on horseback and dismounts at the tavern a coaching station. INT. MAIN ROOM, HURST & WILFORD -- DAY. Reginald enters. His father warms himself by the fire.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Father!

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: Good afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: How extraordinary for you to be here... Sir Reginald stands by the fire, very reserved. REGINALD (CONT’D) You are in good health, I trust? How is Mother? Sir Reginald continues silently by the fire. REGINALD (CONT’D) What brings you here?

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: I won’t dissemble and say I have business in this district -- what I’ve come about is more important.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: What’s of such importance?  18.

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: I know young men don't admit inquiry into affairs of the heart. But, as the sole son of an ancient family, you must know that your conduct is most important to us -- your happiness, ours, the credit of our family name, its very survival--

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: But Father--

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: No, no, hear me out. I know you would not deliberately form an engagement without informing us but I cannot help fear that you'll fall into an obligation which everyone near you must oppose.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: What do you mean, Sir?

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: Lady Susan Vernon's age alone--

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Father, you astonish me!

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: What surprises you?

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Imputing such ambitions to Lady Susan! She'd never think of such a thing; even her enemies grant her excellent understanding. My sole interest has been to enjoy the lively conversation of a superior lady. But Catherine’s prejudice is so great--

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: Prejudice? Lady Susan’s neglect of her late husband, her extravagance and dissipation, her encouragement of other men, were so notorious--

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: These are vile calumnies -- I could explain each but will not so dignify them. I know you spend little time in Society--  19.

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: None.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Should you have frequented it more you'd know the astonishing degree of vile, hateful jealousy in our country--

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: Do not deprecate our country, Sir! I can’t prevent your inheriting the family estate and my ability to distress you during my life is not the kind of revenge that I would choose to take--

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Father, this is unnecessary--

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: No, no, let me continue. A permanent connection between you and Lady Susan Vernon would destroy every comfort of our lives: It would be the death of the honest pride with which we’ve always considered you-- we’d blush to see you, to hear of you, to think of you.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Father, with the utmost humility let me say that what you imagine is... impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A somber Mrs. Cross follows two footmen carrying her trun down the stairs. Lady Susan follows the group, a pleasant expression on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Susan watches from a window as the footmen help Mrs. Cross and her trunk into the carriage. Charles Vernon, morning post in hand, joins her to watch the carriage dep

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Poor Mrs. Cross was obliged to accept a position in Buckinghamshire. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As there was an element of friendship between us I realized the paying of wages would be offensive to us both.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: You value friendship highly.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes. I hope I was of some help to her. Charles, separating one letter from the others:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Your friends don't neglect you. Some distance away Reginald pretends to be reading a book Cowper's poems but his attention is all on Susan as she t the letter expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Charles. Looking at the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, it's from Frederica's school... As Charles moves off she finds a letter opener, slits ope the envelope and begins to read; her face falls.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No..! Agitated she sits and continues to read - Reginald goes t her.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can't believe it! It.. defies comprehension!

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Frederica has run away!... Run away from school!

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Heavens -- where to?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: They don't know.  21.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: She's lost?!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No -- they detected her plan early enough to intercept her. But what folly! Where could she have thought of going?

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Surely, here.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No, this is the last place she’d come; I mean, rather--

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: But she must miss you terribly--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Certainly -- I just don’t think Churchill would be her object. Susan continues reading the letter -- then reacts:

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is outrageous! Miss Summers requires that Frederica be removed from school!... No! This will not stand!... Perhaps Miss Summers is under the impression that, as a widow without fortune, I may be bullied. She's evidently forgotten: Frederica is a Vernon! Lady Susan stands and looks out the window in agitated thought.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Charles must put this right: Confronted with his imposing worth, even the mistress of a school must be persuaded to act rightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles and Lady Susan in a carriage heading for London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Susan walks with Alicia Johnson in the elegant setti  22.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I had no notion of Frederica being so contrary -- she seemed all Vernon milkiness -- but it confirms the rightness of my plan. Did Sir James call?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Several times.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Excellent!

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: I followed your instructions, scolding him roundly for making love to Maria Manwaring -- he protested that it had only been in joke! You are right: he's wonderfully silly. In view across the courtyard an ARISTOCRATIC MAN followed a footman has noticed the ladies and slowly approaches th They continue walking, Susan reflecting:

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: But we can’t let Sir James forget with whom he’s in love -- a man so rich and foolish will not remain single long.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Sir James is so far from having forgotten the Vernons I’m sure he would marry either of you in an instant... Susan smiles and nods, a non-verbal “thank you.”

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I must go back to Churchill -- but I might need your help finding another school should Miss Summers not take her back. Under no circumstance will I have her at Churchill.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Very wise...

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What do you mean?  23.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: The nearness of their ages... Susan looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Her and Reginald’s... As the implication dawns Susan is displeased.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: How unkind...

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Forgive me!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (suddenly sunny) Forgiven! The Fallacy of Youth! Isn’t it rather clear we, women of decision, who hold the trumps!

dialogues.speaker: ARISTOCRATIC MAN
dialogues.text: Lady Susan? Lady Susan Vernon? Lady Susan turns, slow-basting the man with a scathing lo

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: How dare you address me, Sir! The ARISTOCRATIC MAN looks stunned.

dialogues.speaker: ARISTOCRATIC MAN
dialogues.text: But Lady Susan--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Be gone, Sir! Or I will have you whipped! The man turns and slinks away shame-faced.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Outrageous! You had never seen him before?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Oh, no, I know him well. I would never speak to a stranger that way. Alicia considers this and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Susan in a carriage returning from London on her own Music plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful establishing shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reginald and Lady Susan walk in the gardens:

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I hope that you might soon know my friend Alicia -- she’s an American, from the Connecticut branch of the Delancey family. Although even the best-bred Americans don’t sound particularly “fine,” there’s a freshness to her manners which I find rather tonic. Her family were treated outrageously there in the late war, punished for their very loyalty to the Crown. Americans have shown themselves to be a nation of ingrates -- only having children can one begin to understand such a dynamic.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catherine Vernon, carrying an envelope, searches the room finally finding whom she seeks entering the Gold Room fro the garden direction.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Susan, I've been looking for you -- the afternoon coach brought this note. Perhaps Charles has succeeded with Miss Summers... Susan opens the note and reads a few lines.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Oh it's as I feared! Miss Summers refuses to keep Frederica -- she says she must think of her school's reputation--  25.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Preposterous! I never heard of her school! The sound of arrivals come from the front of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles Vernon accompanied by a shy girl of eighteen approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group notices the sound.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Could that be them?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What, Frederica? Here? Charles and Frederica appear in their travelling clothes. Frederica is young, quietly attractive, and terrified.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Hullo, hullo. Well, here we are...

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Is this Frederica?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Yes, allow me to introduce our niece -- charming girl -- Miss Frederica Vernon.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Welcome, Frederica! We've longed to know you.... My brother, Reginald DeCourcy.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Hullo. Pleased to meet you. Frederica bows to all but finally is left facing her moth

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Frederica.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: (voice breaking) Good afternoon, Mother.  26. Looking at her mother Frederica bursts into tears and run from the room.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me. It's as I feared -- I must go to my daughter. Susan leaves.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: What was that? Extraordinary.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Poor Frederica.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Poor mother of Frederica!

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: The daughter is, I understand, a problem case.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I only saw fear.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: She hasn’t had tea. It could be lack of nourishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan and Reginald walk on a garden path; he looks around

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Where is Frederica?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: In our rooms practicing the pianoforte.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: She practices quietly. They both listen for the notes -- Susan glances quickly b

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Don't look -- Frederica's watching us.  27.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Watching us?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes, at the window -- don't look.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: How odd. To be spied upon.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (laughs) That's the parent's lot. We bring these delightful creatures into the world -- eagerly, happily -- but before long they are spying upon and judging us -- rarely favorably. Having children is our fondest wish -- but, in doing so, we breed our acutest critics. A preposterous situation -- but entirely of our own making. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: I marvel at your good humor.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What alternative have we? It’s the way of the world. We must accept it with a smile. (she smiles) Of course when the little ones are very small there's a kind of sweetness which partially compensates for the dreadfulness which comes after...

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: You worry for Frederica’s future?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I worry for her present: (laughs) Frederica's neither pretty nor accomplished, with no conversation-- I say this with a mother’s love, (sincerely, moved) accepting that the responsibility for securing her future rests with me... She looks to Reginald with a sincere, candid expression w he returns.  28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catherine and Reginald are together.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: She’s quite prettier than I ever imagined.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Pretty? You think so?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Yes. You don’t?

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: No. I’d not have said that. In any case, beauty matters little; it’s vivacity and a lively intelligence one looks for -- even from the young. A commotion can be heard outside, Catherine heads toward door but as she does a distraught Frederica bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m sorry. Excuse me-- Embarrassed to find Reginald there, she stops.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: What is it, my dear?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: He’s here! He’s come! Sir James is here!

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: Excuse me. I'm sorry-- Frederica leaves, hurrying to her room; a subdued Susan enters with Sir James Martin.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: So sorry to come like this. (laughs) I suppose you didn't expect me. (laughs)  29. Lady Susan is not amused; she proceeds crisply.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Catherine, let me introduce Sir James Martin. Sir James, my sister in law, Mrs. Catherine Vernon and her brother, Mr. Reginald DeCourcy.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: Hullo.

dialogues.speaker: THE OTHERS
dialogues.text: How do you do? Sir James, surprised by the question, takes a moment to consider it:

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: Kind of you to ask: Excellent. Truly very well, thank you... Excuse my hurry in coming -- the lack of notice beforehand, et cetera, et cetera... (laughs) Truth is, I forgot to write -- then it was too late. Now I'm here... (laughs) Took the liberty of a relation, hoping soon to be one. He nods in the direction Frederica, laughs; the others ar silent. Sir James turns to Lady Susan.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I must say, you looked surprised. (laughs) You were astonished to see me. No? Not? Well, that's how it looked. (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes, I was astonished -- and still am.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: (to Reginald) An impressive establishment you have here, Sir. My congratulations. Immaculate.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Mr. DeCourcy is Mrs. Vernon's brother--  30.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: Very good!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: --it's her husband, Mr. Vernon, who has Churchill.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: Churchill? That's how you say it? All-together that way: (very, very quickly) “Churchill.” (marvelling) That explains a great deal. I had heard “church” ...and “hill” -- but I couldn’t find either. All I saw was a big house. (laughs) Fine name: “Churchill.” Marlborough, right? The general. He showed the French! (laughs; to Catherine) You must be very proud.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: No connection.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: But I believe I’ve heard it spoken of. (to Susan) I think you mentioned it -- “Churchill” -- yes, I believe you did but what I heard was “church” and “hill.” Couldn’t find them at all! Now I realize I was in mistake but stand corrected. Happens quite a lot. Sir James lets loose a long and very silly laugh. When it ends Susan continues:

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Reginald, would you be so kind as to take Sir James to see Charles? Sir James, you'll find Charles well versed in the advanced agricultural methods in which you’ve taken such an interest. Sir James thinks.  31.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: Oh yes! Advanced agricultural methods -- very much so. Collins, who supervises Martindale for me, speaks of them often... The landowner of the present day... must know all sorts of things -- that’s our role. (laughs) "Hullo, Collins” -- I say -- “what advanced methods have we today?" Excellent! For a moment the others just regard Sir James with surpri INT. CHURCHILL, SUSAN’S ROOMS -- LATE PM Susan enters and tries to find her way in a darkened spac revealed to be a bedroom suite.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: .-..Oh, there you are! Were you asleep?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: No, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What then? You were hiding from me?... Please explain.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You're a strange girl. What were you up to back there?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Rushing out before Sir James entered the room.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: I couldn't bear to see him.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: “Couldn't bear?" What an ungenerous manner of speech! Frederica doesn’t move or respond.  32.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Frederica dear, Sir James Martin is a kind-hearted young man whose only offense seems to be (with a sweet smile) wanting to provide you a life of comfort. She waits for a response but there is none.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you nothing to say? Frederica shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dear, our present comfortable state is of the most precarious sort. We don't live -- we visit. We are entirely at the mercy of our friends and relations -- as we discovered so painfully at Langford. Here you seem to have won your aunt's affection: (smiles again) I think I served you well there, for I believe she would do anything to spite me. But such a dynamic cannot continue forever.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: But, Mama--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: “But, Mama?” I will not always be here for you to contradict me. If the life of comfort Sir James offers you is not to your taste, what will you do? How will you live?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: I could... teach.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Teach! Had you been more in school you would not consider such a thing! Answer this: When our Lord wrote His Commandments, which one did he consider so important he put it in the fourth position?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: The fourth position?  33.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes, the Fourth Commandment.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: I know the Commandments -- but not their order.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: That’s what comes of an irregular education! The Fourth Commandment...

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: "Thou shalt not...?"

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It’s not a “Shalt not.” It’s a “Shalt.”

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: “Thou shalt?”

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Had I not myself been present I would wonder if you were actually my daughter: (pause, compassionate look) “Honor. Thy. Father. And. Mother.”

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry! Has anything I’ve done dishonored you or Father?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: To “honor” means, among other things, to listen with respect to a parent's sincere counsel.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: But I do listen with respect, Mama. It's just that--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: If you will not pay attention to me perhaps you will to a larger imperative: the Law of the Universe. An offer as splendid as Sir James’ is unlikely to come again. He has offered you the one thing of value he has to give -- his income. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I fear, and reproach myself, for having shielded you for far too long: had I let you starve a little bit more, you would resist much less.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: But at school I was often hungry--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Evidently not hungry enough! In any case the starvation of the schoolhouse is nothing like that of the destitute. Is that what you want?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: No... I can see that Sir James is a kind man and if it were not a question of marriage I could like him. But marriage is for one’s whole life--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Not in my experience. Meanwhile I must ask you not to speak to your aunt or uncle about this matter -- or seek their interference in any way. I insist -- promise... Remember the Commandment.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: Yes, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan and Catherine walk.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Sir James's arrival, and its suddenness, requires some explanation. You were not too surprised, I hope?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: It was unexpected--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes; certainly. To me, as much as anyone. I'm afraid Sir James’ best qualities are not immediately apparent... Certainly, he's no Solomon--  35.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Solomon?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The wise king in the Bible... who had the idea of dividing the infant disputed by two mothers in half, or in two, I can’t recall the exact wording.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Oh yes of course.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: So Sir James is no Solomon -- but how many suitors of great wisdom is a young woman likely to find today?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I don't know--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: None. And I must confess that at times I wonder if such a quality is even desirable in a husband. Catherine looks a bit surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERY TIGHT ON: very round, very green peas -- a knife of silver knocks them about a plate of fine china.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How jolly. Sir James toys with them as Reginald, Catherine, Charles Frederica watch. A pair of footmen stand against the wall

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tiny green balls... Sir James savors a forkful.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mmm, yes, good tasting -- quite sweet. What are they called?

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Peas.  36.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: Oh yes. I knew that. I recall now. I must get Collins to cultivate them at Martindale. Novelty vegetable -- could make quite a packet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles Vernon catches Catherine for a word -- Sir James be seen circling Frederica in the Gold Room; Reginald sta by the fireplace pretending to read his Cowper volume.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: I’m enjoying Sir James's visit. His conversation is lively, he brings a new angle to things. What do you think if I took him to see the Fredericksville farm? He’s mentioned his interest in agricultural methods...

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The maid brings the Vernon children, Charlotte and Freder down the stairs as Charlotte enjoins her little brother t good.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE CHARLOTTE VERNON
dialogues.text: Frederick, you must try to be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overlapping with the children’s voices, Frederica reads a volume of Cowper’s poems by candlelight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reginald - vexed - joins Lady Susan walking in the garden

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He’s utterly ridiculous.  37.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Certainly he's no Solomon but--

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: “Solomon?”

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The wise king from the bible; I know he’s not that. But any man, navigating the cascades of romantic courtship, and occasionally falling into those foaming waters, is not apt to appear at his best--

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: What? Susan walks away as if vexed, then turns around:

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: A simple word, Reginald: “Comprehension.” I admire your cast of mind but you might not be entirely sensible of the degree to which you intimidate others -- particularly a young man over whom you've every advantage of position, looks and character.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Sir James Martin is a fool because of me?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Around you he seems very silly.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: He isn't silly around everyone?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: I believe he's given everyone the same impression.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: They have only seen him around you.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: But... you deny Sir James's intentions toward you?  38.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Toward me?!

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: He's clearly besotted with you. Susan laughs, as if pleased and flattered.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No, it's with Frederica he's smitten.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: That's not possible.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: He proposed to her.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: How could such a blockhead even be allowed to court your daughter? It’s incomprehensible.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: This is the incomprehension of the rich and easeful! You can afford to take the high ground and add another layer to your pride. If you realized the full extent of ridiculous manhood a young woman without fortune must humor you would be more generous to Sir James!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hubbub of horses and attendants -- Alicia, in travell clothes, and Lady Susan walk between them.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It’s so good of you to steal away.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: We can only meet through such subterfuges -- Mr. Johnson is relentless; I will not be sent back to Connecticut!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I don’t see he’d believe that association with me would lower your reputation.  39.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But, a question: did Sir James mention to you any plans to come to Churchill?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Heavens no! What folly! How did Mr. DeCourcy react?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I had some gratification there: At first he observed Sir James with an attention not untinged with jealousy. But it was impossible to really torture him as I finally had to reveal that Frederica was Sir James's object. Then he was all astonishment! Left to ourselves I had no great difficulty convincing him I was justified - I can't remember the exact reasoning but it was all comfortably arranged.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: So what’s your verdict on young DeCourcy?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: He's not stupid and has a good deal to say, but I can't help but look with a certain contempt on the fancies of a heart always doubting the reasonableness of its emotions. I vastly prefer the generous spirit of a Manwaring who, deeply convinced of one’s merit, is satisfied that whatever one does is right.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: I know that no one really deserves you but young DeCourcy might be worth having. Susan ponders her dear friend’s advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James, seeking to charm Frederica, interrupts her rea as Charles Vernon and Reginald read nearby.  40.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Frederica, when I came down this morning I couldn't help noticing that you were reading a “book.” Which “book” was that?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: This volume of Cowper’s verse. Frederica shows the book which she had been trying to rea

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: Cowper, the poet? He also writes verse? Most impressive. Reginald jumps in.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Yes, he’s versatile that way.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: So, Frederica, you read both poetry and verse? In this I believe you take after your mother, who knows all sorts of things. Just yesterday she cited to me a story from the Bible about a wise king. This reminded me of many such important accounts one learns in childhood. Perhaps most significant in forming one’s principles is that of the old prophet who came down from the mountain with tablets bearing the Twelve Commandments which the Lord taught us must be obeyed without fail.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: The Twelve Commandments?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: (apologetically) Excuse me, I believe there were only ten.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: Oh really? Only have to obey ten? So, which two to take off then? I would say the one about the Sabbath -- I prefer to hunt.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Well...  41.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: After that, it gets tricky. Most of the “shalt nots” -- don’t murder, don’t covet thy neighbor’s house, or wife -- (laughs) -- one wouldn’t think of doing anyway, as they would be wrong, whether one is allowed to take them off or not. Sir James glances to Frederica to see if his disquisition might have impressed her. Card: “Soon to be a relative, Sir James Martin aids a widow.” INT. CHURCHILL, DOOR TO SUSAN’S ROOMS - NIGHT Sir James Martin speaks to Lady Susan (0.S.) outside the to her rooms.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: No, delighted... Honoured. My pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: LADY SUSAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Would you like me to sign a note?

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: No documents. No “note” necessary. All in the family...or soon to be

dialogues.speaker: LADY SUSAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And the carriage?

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: Oh, yes the carriage. Definitely. Certainly. My pleasure. Honoured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glimpse or partial view of an evening dance party, eith the local Assembly or a private gathering, seeing only th protagonists with a few strangers: Sir James Martin, delighted, dancing with all the ladies; Charles Vernon contentedly observing; all the others, dancing, to varyin degrees uncomfortable (Reginald, Susan, Catherine) or actively distressed (Frederica) but ending on Sir James.  42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles and Reginald, returning from an early hunt, dismo and leave their horses to grooms; Reginald heads toward t house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frederica, sitting with a book, listens to the sound of Reginald’s approaching footsteps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reginald approaches the salon and enters, finding Frederi with her head buried in the book.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Oh, hullo. Good day.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: Good day.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Would you know where I might find your mother?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: I believe she’s gone out.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Gone out? Frederica doesn’t reply.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you all right? Frederica, her head plunged sharply down, first nods -- t freezes, as if about to cry.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is it? Frederica can't reply.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell me: what's wrong? Frederica can't bring herself to speak.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please say.  43.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: Sir, I...I do not know to whom I can apply.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: What is it? Please tell me.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: I am sorry, I shouldn't say anything -- it's that -- you're the only one Mother might listen to.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Why would you say that?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: She pays no one such regard as she does you, except Lord Manwaring.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: What do you mean, Manwaring?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: (panics) No -- I’m sorry -- it’s just that, of all people, I thought Mother would listen most to you.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Let me understand this: it’s that you find Sir James's presence and courtship of you unwelcome? Frederica nods. Frederica, Frederica, panics. REGINALD (CONT’D) If his presence here disturbs you, it is to Charles or my sister to whom you should apply. in some torment, does not immediately reply.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: I - I promised Mother I would not.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. Why would you promise that? realizing she has gone far, is flustered and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a tiny voice) She required it.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: What did she require? Frederica freezes. REGINALD (CONT’D) What?... These silences are vexing...

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: Mama forbade it.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: I promised not to speak to my Aunt and Uncle on this subject.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: For what possible reason?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: It’s wrong of me to speak now. If I were not at my wit's end I would not have -- I can't marry Sir James!

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: To what do you object?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: You must have noticed -- he's very silly.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: But besides that.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: Besides that?

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Yes. I confess, the first impression I had of him was also... indifferent. But don’t those knowledgable of such matters consider Sir James a good “catch,” or “match,” or whatever it is they say? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man of cheerful temperament, happy to devote a large income to a wife's comfort?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: I'd rather work for my bread!

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: But what could you do?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: I could teach! I could--

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Teach?!

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: You must have been very little in school. Tell me: how did this happen? Your mother is a woman of excellent understanding, her concern for you great -- though wise and clear-eyed. How could she be so mistaken if you truly despise Sir James?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: I don’t despise Sir James. I can see his a kind man, with good qualities. He is certainly likeable, and I would be free to truly like him if he were a cousin, or a cousin’s cousin, or a friend, or a friend’s friend, or an in-law, or a step-something -- I just don’t want to be married to him... Reginald stands.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Come. Tell me the particulars. If they are as you say I can’t for the world imagine that your mother would remain deaf to your wishes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catherine sorts through Christmas objects when Reginald enters, red-faced and agitated.  46.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Catherine, I'd like to thank you for this visit.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: You're leaving?

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Yes, I must.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: As you've said it's important that, at this season, one of us be with our parents.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: You've just decided this now?

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Yes. But before going I must ask one thing: I’d be grateful if you could see justice is done Frederica. She’s a sweet girl who deserves a better fate.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I'm glad you now see her worth.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Yes, my eyes have opened to many things....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frederica walks toward the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frederica enters and sits near Catherine.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: Aunt, I did something very wrong--

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I’m sure not-- Catherine goes to her.  47.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: No, I did. And now he and my mother have quarrelled: he's to leave and it's my fault! Mama will never forgive me--

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. If any of what you fear comes to pass, I’1l happily intercede...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frederica returning to her room. INSERT: A hand grabs a packet of “Dr. Preston’s Lozenges”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Susan enters, in a seemingly placid mood.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Catherine. That cough of young Frederick's worries me -- I have from London some of Dr. Preston’s excellent lozenges. Could you use some for the dear boy? She hands Catherine the package.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I’ve also a request: Could you tell me if it’s true that we will be losing Mr. DeCourcy today?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Yes, it seems that we will.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: How remarkable. When he and I spoke, barely an hour ago, he mentioned nothing of it. Susan looks into Catherine’s face to divine an answer.  48.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Perhaps he did not then know himself. (a laugh) Young men are so impetuous in their resolutions--

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't say Reginald is impetuous--—

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Oh yes, he is -- he's like other young men that way: Hasty in making resolutions, but just as quick to unmake them! I'd be very surprised if he were not to change his mind and stay.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: He seemed quite decided.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (smiles) We'll see... (leaving) Some strangeness also seems to be affecting Frederica -- I believe the girl's actually fallen in love, with your brother the object!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson knocks at a door; Reginald, jacketless, opens it.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Sir, Lady Susan asks if she might have a word with you She asked if you would be so kind as to visit her in her dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reginald, dressed, ascends the stairs, a determined expression on his face. He knocks on the door.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Come in.  49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reginald enters -- half sheepish, half self-righteous. Fo long moment Susan says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon for the liberty of calling you here, Sir, but I’ve just learned of your intention to leave today. Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Yes, it is.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I entreat you not, on my account, to shorten your visit by even an hour.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Well--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I am perfectly aware that after what has passed between us it would ill-suit either of us to remain in the same house: It’s I who should go.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: No. Why? Lady Susan raises her hand.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: My visit has already been inconvenient for your family; for me to stay risks dividing a clan affectionately attached to one another. Where I go is of little consequence whereas your presence is important to all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A somber Reginald leaves Lady Susan’s rooms.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It's terrifying how close I came to destruction...
Susan has just arrived; Alicia Johnson meets her in the h

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It all started with Frederica, in the grip of a madness of some kind, entreating Reginald to intercede on her behalf -- as if I were some unkind mother not wanting the best for my child. They pass from the hall into the salon.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Next Reginald appears at my rooms with an expression of the utmost solemnity to inform me of the impropriety of allowing Sir James Martin to court Frederica! I tried to joke him out of it but he refused to be.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Heavens, is he really so pompous--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The pomposity I assume; it’s his disloyalty which outraged me! If he held me in true regard he would not believe such insinuations in my disfavour! A worthy lover should assume one has unanswerable motives for all one does!

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Certainly-- Susan pauses, continuing in a softer register.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Scarcely an hour had gone by when I learned Reginald was leaving Churchill: Something had to be done; condescension was necessary though I abhor it. I sent for Reginald; when he appeared he seemed astonished at the summons, and looked as if half-wishing, half- fearing, to be softened by what I might say-- The outcome justifies some portion of vanity, my dear, for it was no less favorable than immediate.  51.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: You brilliant creature.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: So now I have many tasks: I must punish Frederica for her application to Reginald, punish him for receiving it so favorably, and make myself serious amends for the humiliations I've been obliged to undergo.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Manwaring’s in town.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Manwaring! How is he, the divine man?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Absolutely miserable about you and jealous of DeCourcy -- to such a degree I can't answer for his not committing some great imprudence such as following you to Churchill--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Heavens!

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: I think I persuaded him from it. If you do follow my advice and marry DeCourcy, it will be indispensable for you to get Manwaring out of the way. Only you have the influence to send him home.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (thoughtful) And by remaining in Town I'll be able to reward a long penance at Churchill with a little welcome dissipation. A footman enters.

dialogues.speaker: FOOTMAN
dialogues.text: Madam, Lord Manwaring has arrived and begs to be admitted. Alicia and Susan exchange a look; Susan nods.  52.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Please ask him to wait. Susan checks her perfection in a mirror, as the servant leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky dark and threatening Frederica, bundled against t cold, walks a forlorn path, the estate church visible or before her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frederica sits in a side pew by a stained glass window, h bent in meditation or prayer.

dialogues.speaker: CURATE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Miss Vernon? It’s so good to see you here! The affable young CURATE stands before her.

dialogues.speaker: CURATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Might I help you?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: Yes... A friend was asking how, in accord with Christian teaching, the Fourth Commandment should be honored...

dialogues.speaker: CURATE
dialogues.text: The Fourth Commandment? Yes -- “Remember the Sabbath day, to keep it holy.”

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: No, I meant the Commandment, “Honor thy Father and Mother...”

dialogues.speaker: CURATE
dialogues.text: Oh, the Fifth Commandment -- my favorite! It’s the Church of Rome that has it as the Fourth-- yes, the Fifth Commandment: (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CURATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Honour thy father and thy mother: that thy days may be long upon the land which the Lord thy God giveth thee.” Beautiful, profound -- I believe one should apply this sentiment of Gratitude and Loyalty to every aspect of our lives. We are not born into a savage wilderness but in a beautiful mansion of the Lord that the Lord and those who have gone before us have constructed. We must avoid neglecting this mansion but rather glorify and preserve it -- as we should all of the Lord’s Creation. The superb Baumgarten has outlined this aesthetic trinity as “Beauty,” “Truth,” and “Good.” “Truth” is the perfect perceived by reason; “Beauty,” by the senses; and the “Good” by moral will. Frederica looks greatly inspired by the Curate’s words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frederica, returning to Churchill, encounters Reginald returned from a ride. He looks surprised.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: From where do you come?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: Church.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Why were you in church?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: Well... it is our religion.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Yes, but this time of day -- neither morning prayer nor vespers? Frederica, dodging an explanation.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: The sky had clouded over -- I was sure there would be a downpour.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: There was...  54. Reginald shakes some water from his clothes. Frederica no sees that he’s soaking wet, water dripping from his cloth

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: Oh you are quite drenched! You must get into some dry clothes! She moves forward protectively, her hands touching him an then withdraws them embarrassedly as if having touched a surface.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh excuse me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady DeCourcy greets Catherine still in her travelling cl

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: Dearest, welcome!

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Oh, mother! Embracing her and almost crying.

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: What joy your letter gave us!

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I wrote too hastily--

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I couldn't imagine that every expectation I had would be dashed so quickly.

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: You frighten me.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Poor girl -- her one chance to break free... Who knows what punishment her mother will now impose.

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: But Reginald can't be blind to such a lovely girl.  55.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: He’s become blind: Reginald is more securely Lady Susan’s than ever.

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: Please don't tell your father - I worry for his constitution. Sir Reginald appears from the hallway:

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: Tell me what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan’s carriage arrives at Edward Street and she steps o Alicia intercepts her from the front door.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Susan! Stop! Alicia runs down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dreadful news - Mr. Johnson's been cured!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: How is that possible?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: No sooner had he heard you were in London than he had a cure.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Then could you do me the greatest favor? Could you go to Seymour Street and receive Reginald there. I dare not risk his and Manwaring’s meeting -- keep him with you all evening if you can. Make up anything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reginald arrives in a carriage and steps out, dodging a h in the pavement where workmen replace cobblestones. He approaches the stairs to Lady Susan’s building.  56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reginald and Susan enter together.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I wasn’t here to greet you but didn’t I provide a charming substitute? Reginald remains silent - evidently pouting.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's strange: You remain silent but Mrs. Johnson couldn’t stop singing your praises.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I fear Alicia has rather fallen in love with you - it’s given me quite a scare.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: You're joking.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: But you did like her?

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Of course--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I so admire Alicia: she has none of the uncouthness one expects from Americans but all of the candor. Her husband, Mr. Johnson, is older and rather disagreeable but a word of complaint never drops from Alicia's lips. Exemplary. Only by one’s friends can one truly be known; that Alicia is mine will, I hope, help you think better of me.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: I already thought well of you. Susan thinks.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You were not “plagued by doubt?”  57.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Some things disconcerted me: That you were not here, that--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Please, Reginald, don't be severe -- I can't support reproaches...

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: But--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No, I entreat you, I can't support them. My absence was to arrange a matter so that we could be together. I'm forbidden to say more; please don’t reproach me.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Have you considered what I asked?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I have and I believe our affairs require a delicacy and caution which, in our candid enthusiasm, we have perhaps insufficiently heeded--

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I fear our feelings have hurried us to a degree which ill accords with the views of the world.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: I'm sure, in time--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Perhaps, with time, but given the poignancy of our feelings--

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: You no longer wish to marry?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No, no, no. All I'm saying - or hesitantly suggesting - is that we postpone an open understanding until the opinion of the world is more in accord with our own inclinations.  58.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: When might that be? Susan considers the question.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I would say we should let the opinions of our friends be our guide.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: That could mean never!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No, no. Perhaps... months. I confess that such delay is against all my inclinations--

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Then let’s--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No, I can’t be responsible for dividing your family.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: I thought we’d decided.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I know such delays seem insupportable, especially when we are both in London. With separations, only those that are also geographical can reasonably be tolerated.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Reginald: staying in London would be the death of our reputations. We must not meet. And not to meet, we must not be near. Cruel as this may seem, the necessity of it will be evident to you.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Where will you go?  59.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Of course it’s necessary that I remain in London -- there are arrangements I must make for us to be together. But on the contrary I know your family craves your company -- especially that elderly gentleman to whom you owe so much. I'd hate to be the cause of an 6loignement between you and your father, who - forgive me - might not have long left.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: There's no reason for worry that I know of -- Father’s rather in his prime.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Oh thank Heavens! So he’s not in decline?

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: He has the usual aches and pains but is overall, I believe, in good health. In any case he'd not want any concern on that account - which he'd consider so much rubbish.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Ah, mortality! Our mortality and that of others -- but most particularly our own -- is the hardest and most implacable hand life deals us. I long to meet the dear gentleman. Of course it's natural that he would want to ignore or minimize the cold, sad end that awaits us.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Not at all. Father's a Christian, for whom the prospect of the end is neither sad nor cold.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Ah, yes! Well thank Heaven for our religion -- so important in this life, and most especially in the next. Reginald paces the room.  60.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Must we really wait? I entreat you to reconsider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A servant opens the door to Lady Manwaring, crying and “fretted thinner and uglier than ever,” accompanied by tw servants including OWEN.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Lady Manwaring!

dialogues.speaker: LADY MANWARING
dialogues.text: (in tears) Excuse me.. I'm in.. such a state, I don’t know what to say... Is Mr. Johnson at home? (close to sobbing) I must speak with my guardian.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, of course. You poor dear! I'll let him know you're here. Alicia leads her into the salon and puts her head into th library.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lucy Manwaring is here to see you.

dialogues.speaker: LADY MANWARING
dialogues.text: (howling) Mr. Johnson! Lady Manwaring lunges into the library and disappears wit

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Yes, please go in.

dialogues.speaker: LADY MANWARING, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You must help! You must help me! Manwaring’s left! Alicia closes the door but leans close to hear.

dialogues.speaker: MR. JOHNSON, (0.S. OR PARTIAL)
dialogues.text: Dear Lucy, please, calm yourself. Here, take a seat.

dialogues.speaker: LADY MANWARING, (0.S.)
