dialogues.text: He's gone -- with no intention of returning!  61.

dialogues.speaker: MR. JOHNSON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What exactly’s happened... Please tell me everything, as best you can. A footman enters the salon to announce a visitor.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON FOOTMAN
dialogues.text: Madam, Mr. DeCourcy. Reginald enters.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Oh, good day.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Mr. DeCourcy! She is taken aback but approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What a surprise to see you! So kind of you to call.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: I must thank you for last evening - for setting matters right. Lady Susan has explained everything. I'm ashamed to have spoken as I did -- it was foolish of me--

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: No, no not at all -- most sympathetic... Alicia maneuvers to keep Reginald away from the library, which voices can still be heard.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But you didn't have to come to thank me -- courtesy did not dictate it...

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: In fact it’s not my sole motive -- Lady Susan has entrusted me with a letter for you. Reginald hands her the letter.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: (reading) “Strictly private” - how intriguing.  62. Lady Manwaring's scarcely human high-pitched plaint is to audible to ignore.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Has an animal been injured?!

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Amateur theatricals... “Medea” -- They perform next week but prefer not to be watched rehearsing. Alicia hurries Reginald toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you again for the charming evening. Lady Manwaring bursts out of the library followed Johnson -- Reginald, too close to the door to see unobstructed, catches only glimpses of the drama.

dialogues.speaker: LADY MANWARING
dialogues.text: She’s with him now! This can't continue! It mustn't--

dialogues.speaker: MR. JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Lucy, please don't! Stay here, rest, recover your equanimity--

dialogues.speaker: LADY MANWARING
dialogues.text: Equanimity!? They're together now! (to Mr. Johnson) I implore you -- come with me, talk with Manwaring, reason with him. As my Guardian, won't you help?--

dialogues.speaker: MR. JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Even if I found them, what good could be done? Alicia has returned partway to the room.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Yes, heed Mr. Johnson, in such matters his counsel is excellent--

dialogues.speaker: LADY MANWARING
dialogues.text: What have you? A letter in her hand! Lady Manwaring snatches the envelope from Alicia. by Mr. them  63.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Return that letter, Madam. It is not for you. Lady Manwaring tears it open.

dialogues.speaker: MR. JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Lucy, no! Reginald snatches the letter, holding it away from her.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Madam, I believe you were on the verge of making a grave error. You are Lady Manwaring? Lady Manwaring of Langford? You've recognized your friend Lady Susan Vernon’s hand and assume the letter’s for you--

dialogues.speaker: LADY MANWARING
dialogues.text: You think that Lady is my friend? She's with my husband now; as we speak, he visits her!

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: That's impossible, Madam. I’ve just left her; she’s entirely alone, even her servant sent off.

dialogues.speaker: LADY MANWARING
dialogues.text: Owen! The Johnson footman leads Lord Manwaring’s servant, OWEN, into the salon. LADY MANWARING (CONT’D) Owen -- come here, stand here. Tell this gentleman what you've seen.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Your ladyship..

dialogues.speaker: LADY MANWARING
dialogues.text: Repeat to him what you told me. Owen turns to Reginald.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Well, Sir, Lady Susan sent her servant away, then you left. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: OWEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A few minutes later Lord Manwaring arrived and was received by her ladyship.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Alone?

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, I believe so. No one else came or went. Lady Manwaring snatches the letter and starts devouring i

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: No - stop! The letter’s for Mrs. Johnson only!

dialogues.speaker: LADY MANWARING
dialogues.text: Here: (reading) "I send Reginald with this letter -- keep him there all evening if you can; Manwaring comes this very hour.”

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: That’s not possible.

dialogues.speaker: LADY MANWARING
dialogues.text: I must stop this! (to Mr. Johnson) Please, Sir, come with me.

dialogues.speaker: MR. JOHNSON
dialogues.text: What could possibly be gained? It could even be dangerous; this is a matter for your solicitors. (turning to Alicia) Mrs. Johnson, this goes beyond what I could imagine -- you promised to give up all contact with this woman .

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: I've no idea what she writes! She’s gone mad!

dialogues.speaker: MR. JOHNSON
dialogues.text: I’m sorry to say, my dear, that I hear the Atlantic passage is very cold this time of year. Alicia is stunned, Lucy Manwaring in hysterics.  65.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. CARRIAGE, LONDON STRETS
dialogues.text: Tight on Alicia’s pensive face as she rides in a carriage

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alicia Johnson arrives, taking off her cloak.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Agonies, my dear!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: The worst. Disaster--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Disaster?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Mr. DeCourcy arrived just when he should not have -- Lucy Manwaring had just forced herself into Mr. Johnson's study to sob her woes.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Has she no pride, no self-respect?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: What an impression she makes -- bursting from Mr. Johnson’s library wailing like a struck child. Seeing the letter in your handwriting, she tore it from Reginald to read aloud-

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Yes. "Manwaring comes this very hour!"

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: And Reginald heard that?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: He read it himself.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: How ungentlemanly! Shocking! I can’t believe it.  66.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Yes, very shocking.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: A gentleman, entrusted with correspondence marked "private," reads it regardless -- and then, because of some confidential remarks, the obloquy is mine! But who has acted badly in this affair? Only you and I stand innocent of reading other people’s correspondence!

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Unluckily Lady Manwaring also wormed out of her husband's servant that Manwaring visited you in private.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Oh. (she contemplates this) Facts are horrid things! Susan paces the room, then recovers.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't worry : I'll make my story good with Reginald. He'll be a little enraged at first but I vow that, by dinner tomorrow, all will be well. Alicia looks more doubtful.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: I’m not sure... He was with Mr. Johnson when I left. Forgive me for saying it but... I dread to imagine what’s being said in your disfavour... Susan stops pacing and regards Alicia with compassion:

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What a mistake you made marrying Mr. Johnson: Too old to be governable, too young to die!  67. EXT. MONTAGE: LONDON IMAGES SUGGESTING A DAY’S PASSING -

dialogues.speaker: DAY/NIGHT
dialogues.text: St. Paul’s on the horizon at sunset or dawn, perhaps peri London stock shots, to be researched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reginald climbs the steps and knocks on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The maid shows Reginald up the stairs -- he is very sombe He enters the salon and addresses Lady Susan.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The maid has her ear to the door eavesdropping on the conversation within. We hear through the door:

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Of course it might seem outlandish or shocking to others--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Susan, in a dressing gown, sits as Reginald stands.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: -- but we are not expecting others to read our correspondence and don’t put things for their benefit. Manwaring only visited me as his wife's friend--

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: "Friend?" She herself denies this.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Of course -- I was her friend when she was sane, her great enemy since. Manwaring left Langford to escape her deranged suspicions. In granting him an interview my sole motive was to persuade him to return to her and see what might be done to ease the poor woman's mind--  68.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: But why “alone?” Why did you arrange to see him alone?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You cannot divine the motive there? Servants have ears, with the unfortunate tendency to repeat whatever they imagine they have hear. I dreaded injuring the poor lady's reputation still further.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: You imagine I could accept such an explanation?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I can only tell you what I know to be true.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Did you succeed?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Did you convince Manwaring to return to his wife?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes. I did. But it seems that her judgment is too deteriorated to allow it. Her suspicious and jealous condition is not one that will accept reassurance.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: You forget, I saw the letter with my own eyes--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No, I do not forget. I greatly resent it -- a fault you compounded by misinterpreting what you should never have seen. Do you think I would have confided a letter to a third party if I thought its contents in any way dangerous? Haven't I already explained everything which the ill-nature of the world might interpret to my discredit? What could so stagger your esteem for me now? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all we've discussed and meant to one another, that you could doubt my intentions, my actions, my word... Reginald is silent.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Reginald. I’ve reflected upon this deeply: I cannot marry a man with an untrusting disposition. I cannot have it.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: (softly, stunned) What?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: We cannot marry. Whatever commitment there was between us is severed; any connection impossible.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Mistrust does not bode well for any union. I have a great regard for you - yes, a passionate one. But I must master it. Distraught, Reginald bows and leaves.
Lady DeCourcy looks out for her daughter in a happy mood.

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: Catherine! Catherine! Catherine Vernon enters from the garden.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: What is it, Mother?

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: Reginald's returned.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: He's here?

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: He's just gone to find your father.  70.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: It's not--

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: No, the most happy news - our fears were in vain.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: The engagement's off!

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: Lady Susan broke it off herself.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: She did? Catherine looks apprehensive.

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: Reginald's most cast down. But I’m sure he'll soon recover and -- dare we hope -- cast his look elsewhere? Catherine thinks further.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: That woman’s a fiend!

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Lady Susan. She has an uncanny understanding of men's natures. A look of worry and confusion crosses Lady DeCourcy’s fac

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: Uncanny?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Reginald will start again to doubt everything he's heard to her detriment; a guilty regret will overwhelm him. Slowly, surely he'll convince himself he’s wronged her.  71.

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: You frighten me!

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Yes, if Frederick Vernon, renowned for good sense, let Lady Susan ruin him -- what chance has Reginald?

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: You speak as if your brother were not wise; everyone comments on his lively intelligence.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: You're the best of mothers but Reginald has just the sort of sincere nature most vulnerable to a woman of her genius--

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: You think she’s a genius?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Diabolically so, like the serpent in Eden's Garden.

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: Does this woman always get her way?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: From what I understand only clever tradesmen are astute enough to see through her stratagems; several banded together to send their agents to intercept her on Seymour Street, obliging her to pawn the last of her jewels. Paces can be heard down the hall: Reginald and his father enter, Reginald cast down while the old man seems in high spirits.

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: Slay the fatted calf, my dear -- the prodigal's returned! He looks to Reginald, a wet blanket. SIR REGINALD (CONT’D) What's wrong, my boy? The joy of seeing your aged parents eludes you? Lady DeCourcy steps off screen.  72.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Don't tease him, Father.

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: It's a father’s right.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: You'll have him fleeing back to London.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: No risk of that I assure you. London holds no charm for me.

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: Oh you've realized that: Good. Never appealed to me at all. Dirty, noisy -- noxious gases, soot... I don't see the point of towns. Far better to live on one’s own land. Everyone should.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I'm afraid this relates to my sister-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Yes, sister -- congratulations on your entire vindication.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: On the contrary, I don't see you out of danger at all.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: I assuredly am.

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: What’s all this about? What's happened? I don’t understand. Lady DeCourcy re-enters with a sheaf of music and blushin Frederica.

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: Reginald dear, Frederica's prepared a charming piece -- help me persuade her to sing it for us.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: Oh, no -- you're too kind, Lady DeCourcy. I’m not ready--  73.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Miss Vernon, Mother: As much as I'd like to, I'm afraid I’m too tired to be a suitable audience- Outside, the sound of a carriage approaching. Catherine REGINALD (CONT’D) So, if you'll excuse me--

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: No, you must stay. Frederica’s a songbird -- never heard anything like it. (to Frederica) Don't deny us this pleasure, my dear. Reginald, we need you to insist.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Well, as I said, I--

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: No, I'm sorry. Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: You must play it, my dear. Please--

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: "The Kentish Nightingale," I call her. Voice's remarkable - even to my hearing.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: She must have it from her mother’s side: Lady Susan’s voice is a clear, natural soprano. Lovely, beautiful... looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: Oh, it is, is it?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Do you expect visitors, Mother?

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: No... Who would visit us? Charles Vernon enters, smiling.  74.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Look who's come from London -- what an agreeable surprise! Lady Susan enters.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me for arriving this way-- Except for Charles the others remain absolutely still.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What a delightful family pose!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Yes, it is the season for families to unite -- so especially welcome to have you here.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Charles! (to Sir & Lady DeC) I do hope that, recognizing a mother's anxiety to see her child, you might excuse my abruptness.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Nothing to excuse. Sir Reginald, Lady DeCourcy -- might I introduce my sister-in-law, Lady Susan Vernon.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Enchanté. Please forgive this intrusion but now that I'm fixed in town I can't rest with Frederica away.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Isn't such anxiety new?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (ever cheerful) Yes, it is -- I entirely agree. But now I’m in London where the instruction Frederica needs can so readily be found. Her voice has some promise--

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: “Some?” She’s a veritable songbird - - "The Kentish Nightingale," I call her.  75.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Do you? Is this really Kent? She takes a glance in the direction of the window and the moonlit night.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How delightful. (Flashes a smile.) You are right, Sir -- Frederica has the native talent a bird might. But those few notes can get repetitive.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: But, Mama, couldn’t I stay?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (repeats) “But, Mama, couldn't I stay?" Charming. (to Catherine) Thank you, dear sister, for making Frederica feel so welcome and at home (to Lady DeCourcy) wherever she goes. (to Frederica) I’ve secured you a lesson with Signore Veltroni. Where the Grand Affair of Education is concerned, there’s no excuse for half- measures! (to Sir Reginald, loudly) Isn't it key to cultivate her voice, Sir? A “nightingale,” didn’t you say? Sir Reginald is a little loud always.

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: Yes, that’s right. The “Kentish Nightingale” I call her.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: A delightful appellation and perhaps, with a teacher such as Signore Veltroni, it could even become true. Frederica, have you your things? LADY DECOURCY. Leave for London now? We’d so looked forward to having Frederica with us.  76.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: How remarkable: Only a few weeks ago it was hard to find anywhere for Frederica, now the World fights for her company! Astonishing.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Astonishing that she was neglected then, or is fought over now?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: An excellent observation, dear sister -- but I will stop now, because I know my daughter hates to be praised. (to Reginald) How are you, Sir? I hope well. (to Frederica) We should go.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mama, I must collect my things.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes, you must -- we can’t buy a new wardrobe for each displacement. Frederica and Susan leave.

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: The poor girl - did you see her face?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I must talk to her and remind her that she'll always have a home with us.

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: (Looking to Sir Reginald) Or us.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: If you are referring to the past I doubt her mother will again risk misinterpretation. Henceforth we can rest assured that Lady Susan will make clear to Frederica the consideration and affection which guide her actions.  77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Susan’s carriage approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alicia and Lady Susan walking along the sculpted paths of Johnsons’ garden.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I’ve not gone to the trouble of retrieving Frederica from Parklands to again be thwarted! Maria Manwaring may sob, Frederica whimper, and the Vernons storm - but Sir James will be Frederica's husband before the winter’s out!

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: You brilliant creature!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, my dear. I’m done submitting my will to the caprices of others; of resigning my own judgment in deference to those to whom I owe no duty and feel little respect. Too easily have I let my resolve weaken: Frederica shall know the difference!

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: You're too indulgent with the girl - - why let Frederica have him, when you could grab him yourself?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Sir James?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Yes. I know your unselfish nature -- but can you afford to bestow Sir James on Frederica while having no Sir James of your own? A look of disagreeable surprise crosses Susan's face. Meanwhile a footman approaches.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON FOOTMAN
dialogues.text: (addressing Alicia) Madam, Mr. Johnson sends word he returns to dine.  78.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (whispers) Are you insulting me?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Just the opposite: I don't doubt your ability to get DeCourcy whenever you want him, but is he really worth having? Isn't his father just the sort of enraging old man who will live forever? How would you survive? On the allowance that Frederica, as Lady Martin, might grant you? As guests at Churchill? I'd rather be married to my own husband than dependent on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catherine folds a letter she has just finished reading to Lady DeCourcy; the season has changed.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: ...We must protect her -- not just for her own but for her dear, late father’s.

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: But what can we do?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: We must find the argument that will persuade her mother it’s in her own interest, which is of course her only guide. That will mean going to London; fortunately Charles must have some business or other there to justify such a trip.

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: What a marvellous husband you have; Charles seems to live to oblige.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: It’s true, I've been lucky -- Charles always seems to have some pretext or other for doing just what's wanted. Charles arrives from down the hall.  79.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dearest, I believe you have pressing business in London.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Oh, um, yes.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT
dialogues.text: Lady Susan leads Charles and Catherine Vernon up the top the stairs toward the salon.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (calling up the stairs) Frederica! (to the Vernons) You're so kind to visit: Frederica will be delighted. How are the children -- especially my dear Frederick?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Very well, thank you--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (calling up the stairs) Frederica, come see who’s here! (to the Vernons) I can't express my gratitude for the hospitality you’ve extended us.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Not at all -- our great pleasure. Frederica comes down the stairs, again in her former fear mode.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Hello, Frederica.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, my dear. I hope you are well.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: Thank you -- it’s so good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Frederica, why don’t you go upstairs and play a piece? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Select something charming to show your aunt and uncle what you’ve studied.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: With pleasure. Frederica leaves.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (to Charles) Do mind your head. He ducks going through the door.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll see the strides she's been making - Frederica plays all the new music: Haydn, Himmel, Bernardini...Cherubini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all sit.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: So you're happy with the progress she’s making?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (a thoughtful pause, quite long) Yes... Only in a city such as London, I believe, could she have had such instruction. Charles turns to Catherine.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Well, if Frederica is making such good progress in London -- that complicates matters...

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What complication would that be?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: We'd hoped Frederica might return to Churchill

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: She's greatly missed, by the little ones especially--  81.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What a moving sentiment of cousinly regard. My concern, my obligation, is to see the defects in Frederica’s education repaired.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Could we invite one of her teachers to Churchill to continue her lessons there?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What a kind thought. But these are London's most sought-after masters; no invitation to a country retreat, even such a delightful one as Churchill, is likely to be in their power to accept.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Perhaps a private tutor then--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Might I confess something? Frederica and I have become such great friends it would be hard for me to part with her. You might have noticed that, for a time, there was a strange tension between us. That has now happily disappeared -- you can imagine how pleased I am. Catherine seems to sag.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Excuse me, are you quite well?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Sorry -- we'd so set our hearts on Frederica’s return.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I understand completely. She's become an agreeable companion -- even her tendency to extreme quiet I’ve grown to find rather soothing. (a brief glance off) But there is one factor that concern me: does she look quite well?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Oh yes.  82.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: That was your impression? London’s vaporous air is not, I worry, quite healthy for her. Does she not seem pale?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: She does. The London air, these smoky gases, cannot be salutary for her. Fresh, country air is what the young require.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes, how curious they are. For a moment an awkward silence descends, broken by Charl

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Does not the town’s dank air favor the spread of influenza?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The influenza? In London?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Several cases have been reported -- it, after all, is the season for it.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Of all the disorders in the world, the risk of an influenza contagion is what I most dread for Frederica's constitution.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Shouldn't we consider then removing her from this danger?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What you say gives me pause... But it'd be such a hardship to lose my daughter's companionship just as I’ve come to rely on it -- and of course her studies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From her house Susan climbs into Mrs. Johnson's carriage, spirit exultant.  83.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Congratulate me, my dear -- Frederica’s aunt and uncle have taken her back to Churchill.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: I thought you’d grown to enjoy Frederica’s company so.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Comparatively. A bit. But I’m not so self-indulgent as to want to wallow in the companionship of a child. The carriage approaches the park.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Alas, I fear this is our last meeting, at least while Mr. Johnson is in life. His business at Hartford has become extensive. If I continue to see you he vows to settle in Con-nect-i-cut forever.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (shocked) You could be scalped!!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (moved, voice tremulous) I always suspected that the great word "Respectable" would one day divide us. Your husband I abhor but we must yield to necessity. Our affection cannot be impaired by it and, in happier times, when your situation is as independent as mine, we will unite again -- for this I shall impatiently wait. She gives Alicia’s hands a last squeeze.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: I also.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: May Mr. Johnson's next gouty attack end more favorably! The carriage pulls to a stop near the palatial archway. Susan steps down from it and looks through the archway to where handsome, romantic Manwaring waits.
A month or more later, the season milder. A long view of figures walking and talking animatedly in the garden -- Frederica and Reginald.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A footman hands Charles Vernon correspondence which he lo through -- one letter attracts his particular attention. Catherine joins him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Do you know where Frederica is? Lady Susan’s written her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catherine looks for Frederica, just returned form her wal

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Frederica.... Frederica!

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: Coming!

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Frederica -- a letter from your mother! Frederica arrives in walking clothes - followed by Regina

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Aunt Catherine. What does she say?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: She's written to you herself. Frederica takes the closed envelope and opens it. joins them.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: My mother and Sir James Martin have wed!

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: What?! How could that happen? How could they possibly marry? Charles  85.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: To what do you refer? Both were free to do so: he a bachelor, Susan a widow.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Sir James Martin is a fool.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Well, a bit of a “rattle,” perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: A bit of a rattle? He’s a complete blockhead!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Well, there are three possible explanations as I see it: first, perhaps Sir James has more merit than we've allowed--

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Second, perhaps, in order to secure your future, Frederica, your mother thought it necessary to make a prudent match herself.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: That could be the case. Mama has always been concerned for my future.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: And the third possible explanation?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: That she -- came to love him. There is a saying - "the heart has its strangeness," or words to that effect. The heart is an instrument we possess but do not truly know. Human love partakes of the divine, or at least has in my case. Charles looks to Catherine who responds with a sweet smil

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I believe you will find it in Rousseau’s writings -- Julie, or the New Heloise I think. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I will confirm the citation if you're interested.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: I just find it incomprehensible that so brilliant a woman could marry such a pea brain... or peas brain.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: This happens all the time. Catherine smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: It strains credulity.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Certainly -- as you’ve said-- (nod to Catherine) Sir James is no “Solomon,” but if he can give Lady Susan the happiness and security which the sad events of recent years deprived her, then he's someone I and all of us should value.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: I very much agree, Uncle, we all should -- I wish them every happiness in their life together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir James Martin, in very good spirits, follows Alicia Johnson into the room.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: I congratulate you, Sir James, on a match I long favored: there’s a rightness to your being together -- not that any man could really deserve Lady Susan.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: I agree most heartily... And I’ve the pleasure of adding that double congratulations are in order.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: What?  87.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: The most beautiful woman in England - present company excepted - will soon be the most beautiful mother. Yes, I’m to be a father.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Marvelous! You certainly don’t delay matters... Congratulations, Sir! The footman brings in the elaborate tea service; Alicia m the tea.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: Yes. The very morning after the wedding Lady Susan hinted at the happy news - which was shortly confirmed.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: How truly marvelous!

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: I'm as proud as you can imagine. The sound of a wheezing sob off screen.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: (whispers) Such a burden. When Lord and Lady Manwaring separated, Mr. Johnson -- who was Lucy Manwaring’s guardian -- invited her to live with us.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: Really? What upsets her?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: The separation still. She keeps on about it.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: All this carrying on about a marriage that ended weeks ago. If a woman fails to please her husband -- why go on about it, advertising one’s failure? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why announce to the world that the man who knows you best would rather be with someone else?

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: It seems as if Lady Manwaring has failed to consider the difference between the sexes. For a husband to wander is not the same as vice versa. If a husband strays, he’s merely responds to his biology - that is how men are made. (smiling complacently) But for a woman to act in a similar way is ridiculous, unimaginable. Just the idea is funny: (laughs) Hew, hew, hew... hew, hew.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Oh yes -- couldn’t agree more, quite funny: ha, ha, ha. They sit. From the silver samovar Alicia pours the water over the tea.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: I rather blame Lady Manwaring’s scene-making for driving her husband away. But her loss has been our gain. As a result of all the trouble her solicitors caused, we've had him with us these past weeks.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: That’s not inconvenient?

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: Not at all. Capital fellow. Couldn’t get on better -- loves to hunt, small and large game. Excellent to have a guest and the talk which comes with it. Of course Lady Susan's sharp but it's easier to talk with a fellow, particularly one who shares one’s interests.... Before long we'll have another guest.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Frederica?  89.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: (laughs) No. Of course, the baby. The door bursts open - Lady Manwaring, distraught and disheveled, enters.

dialogues.speaker: LADY MANWARING
dialogues.text: Manwaring? Manwaring? Have you seen my husband? What have you been saying, Sir? Tell me. How... is he?

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: Well, Madam, very well, I believe. Couldn't be better. Lady Manwaring leaves sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: ALICIA
dialogues.text: Tea?

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: Quite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As guests enter the chapel Sir James Martin’s carriage pu up. Sir James Martin, a very pregnant Lady Susan, and Manwaring alight from it, Sir James stepping slightly ahe

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: (pleased, then confused) So, here’s the Church! But, where’s the hill? Don’t see it. (looking around) Doesn’t seem to be one -- strange. Odd. Sir James steps toward the portal as other guests enter t church. Manwaring looks handsome -- and content.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immediately after the wedding, guests crowd around the po holding the green garland arch. The crowd cheers & throws wheat as the newlyweds -- Frederica and Reginald -- pass beneath. LITTLE CHARLOTTE VERNON, advancing with her pare Catherine and Charles Vernon calls out to the couple:

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE CHARLOTTE VERNON
dialogues.text: God bless you all!  90. INT. CHURCHILL, MAIN HALL -—- DAY The joyous arrival of wedding guests to the hall of Churc for cake and further celebration, within which there are small groupings: --A footman places a beautiful light blue wedding cake on table. --Frederica with Charles Vernon and Sir Reginald and Lady DeCourcy:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Your mother must be very proud.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: And I am enormously grateful to her. Without my mother’s efforts I would never have found such happiness. Do excuse me. --The Young Curate speaks with Catherine Vernon:

dialogues.speaker: CURATE
dialogues.text: Oh, no. That would be the Ninth. --Lady Susan, Manwaring and Sir James Martin in another grouping:

dialogues.speaker: SIR JAMES
dialogues.text: You must be most proud of Frederica.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I would not say “proud” -- I am glad that I was able to attend to her Education. My daughter has shown herself to be cunning and manipulative -- I couldn’t be more pleased: A Vernon will never go hungry. Sir James raises a cheerful toast while Susan and Manwari exchange a passionate glance. --Sir Reginald and Lady DeCourcy with Charles Vernon:

dialogues.speaker: LADY DECOURCY
dialogues.text: We must ask Frederica to sing.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: That would be delightful. (confiding) The “Surrey Songbird,” we call her.  91. Sir Reginald seems irritated.

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: What? No, she’s the Kentish Nightingale -- always call her that. “Surrey Songbird” -- nonsense, rubbish... ridiculous. Wilson the butler announces:

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, Mr. Reginald DeCourcy! --The crowd turns to Reginald, standing with a beaming an lovely Frederica:

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Over the past months I have continued to be startled by Frederica’s loveliness and good- heart. I had wanted to write some verses as a memorial to these discoveries -- but they are now so extensive they would form a volume so I will just read these few lines: (reading from his notes) Blest tho' she is with ev'ry human grace, The mien ["mean"] engaging, and bewitching face... Sir Reginald looks confused:

dialogues.speaker: SIR REGINALD
dialogues.text: “Mien engaging?”

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Yes, “mien” -- appearance or countenance -- from the French “mine,” I believe. I could find you the reference. On the raised steps Reginald completes reciting the verse Frederica:

dialogues.speaker: REGINALD
dialogues.text: Yet still an higher beauty is her care, Virtue, the charm that most adorns the fair.  92. The crowd cheers -- various reaction shots from the other side of the room. Sir James Martin, particularly pleased, raises his glass in a toast, Lady Susan and Manwaring exchange a devoted look. --On the raised steps now Frederica alone and a happy Reginald below continues:

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA
dialogues.text: As you may already know I take Lady DeCourcy’s requests as commands and therefore I will sing this piece... The crowd gathers to hear.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (sings) Over the mountains And over the waves, Under the fountains And under the graves, Under floods that are deepest, Which Neptune obey Over rocks that are the steepest, Love will find out the way. As Frederica sings, her voice beautiful, the reaction sho from all concerned, the very pregnant Lady Susan and othe ending with Sir Reginald and Lady DeCourcy’s affectionate embrace.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You may esteem him A child for his might, Or you may deem him A coward from his flight. But if she, whom Love doth honor, Be concealed from the day Set a thousand guards upon her, Love will find out the way. As the music swells, credits roll.
